Pain in leg, unspecified M79.606 ; Disorder of vein, unspecified I87.9 ; Leg numbness R20.0 ; Leg swelling M79.89 ; Leg cramping R25.2 ; Tingling of both feet R20.2 ; Dizziness R42 ; Leg heaviness R29.898 ; Abnormal ankle brachial index (ABI) R68.89 ; Venous insufficiency I87.2 ; Temporal headache R51.9 ; Itchy skin L29.9 ; Burning sensation of skin R20.8 ; Restless legs syndrome G25.81 and Leg edema R60.0

td.paragraph: A
post-procedure venous ultrasound done today was negative for DVTs.
Physical exam revealed bilateral 2+ pitting edema, right greater than
left, but no pain or bruising. Pedal pulses were intact. The patient
will continue compression therapy and leg elevation as tolerated. We
reassured her based on negative post-procedure duplex ultrasound
findings. We advised monitoring for any new or worsening symptoms
such as redness, worsening swelling, or signs of infection. A
follow-up visit is scheduled for 07/27 to continue cardiovascular
evaluation and assess for further interventions. All questions and
concerns answered and addressed. Heart healthy diet and healthy
lifestyle modifications were encouraged and endorsed. Patient
expressed understanding and agreed with the management plan.

tr.td: well developed, well nourished, in no acute distress
neck is supple, full range of motion, no thyromegaly, no cervical lymphadenopathy
regular rate and rhythm, S1, S2 normal, no murmurs, gallops, clicks or rubs, no JVD, carotid upstroke brisk bilaterally, no carotid bruit
symmetrical chest expansion, clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes, rales, rhonchi, normal respiratory effort, no labored breathing
soft, non-tender, non-distended, bowel sounds present in all four quadrants
nonfocal, alert, awake and oriented to person, place and time
full range of motion, no upper extremity edema, 2+ pitting edema

td.paragraph: This is an 80-year-old female with a significant medical history of hypertension, obesity, peripheral vascular disease, hyperlipidemia, and gastroesophageal reflux disease, who presents today for CV follow-up post RVV venous ablation performed on 06/29. She reports ongoing lower extremity heaviness, aching, swelling, itching, and burning at sites of visible bulging varicosities. She has remained compliant with conservative measures including daytime compression stockings and leg elevation and resting at night. Post-ablation, she reports partial improvement in symptoms. She denies chest pain, chest pressure, syncope, or near syncopal episodes.
ABI/PVR: RLE 0.79, LLE 0.54.
Venous reflux: Significant venous reflux in bilateral lower extremities.
Temporal artery doppler:Negative for any inflammation.
BLE venous doppler: Negative for any evidence of DVT.
Venous ultrasound: No evidence of DVT.
Venous doppler: Negative for DVT.

A post-procedure venous ultrasound done today was negative for DVTs. Physical exam revealed bilateral 2+ pitting edema, right greater than left, but no pain or bruising. Pedal pulses were intact. The patient will continue compression therapy and leg elevation as tolerated. We reassured her based on negative post-procedure duplex ultrasound findings. We advised monitoring for any new or worsening symptoms such as redness, worsening swelling, or signs of infection. A follow-up visit is scheduled for 07/27 to continue cardiovascular evaluation and assess for further interventions. All questions and concerns answered and addressed. Heart healthy diet and healthy lifestyle modifications were encouraged and endorsed. Patient expressed understanding and agreed with the management plan.
